_prev_prog_3.Description: Mountain View Cold Storage has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program.  The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements.  At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119).  This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Mountain View Cold Storage has elected to use PSMWriter©, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Mountain View Cold Storage, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Mountain View Cold Storage has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name          | Process Chemical         | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration   Anhydrous Ammonia          40,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.



Mountain View Cold Storage has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overal

l plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Mountain View Cold Storage business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary Mountain View Cold Storage employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.



1.2 Process Description



Facility Layout



Mountain View Cold Storage operates a commercial cold storage facility in Reedley, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:



(5) Cold storage rooms

(4) Precool rooms

(1) Loading dock

(1) Summeripe room 



Refrigeration System Equipment



The refrigerated spaces are equipped with air-cooling evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation.



All control valve groups are located on the roof to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within a refrigeration machinery room. A partial list of system components includes:



Machinery Room

(5) Screw compressors

(5) Oil separators

(4) Shell and tube oil coolers

(1) Plate and frame oil cooler

(2) High pressure receivers

(1) Liquid transfer vessel

(1) Main suction accumulator

(1) Thermosyphon vessel



Condenser Area

(3) Evaporative condensers



Loading Dock

(1) Air-cooling evaporator (ceiling-suspended)



Storage Rooms

(5) Accumulators

(21) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral finned)



Precool Rooms

(7) Accumulators

(13) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral finned)

(5) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, plate finned)



Summeripe Room

(2) Accumulators

(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)



Process Chemistry



The refrigeration system employed at Mountain View Cold Storage

is configured for flooded operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in the system is summarized below:



High Pressure Receiver



The purpose of the high pressure receiver is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration system. The two (2) high pressure receivers receive high pressure liquid from the condensers and thermosyphon vessel and supply high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. The high pressure receivers are equipped with a single main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Flooded Accumulator



The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the main suction accumulator. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)



The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulator. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a grea

t deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporator (Direct Expansion)



The purpose of the air-cooling evaporator is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The Loading Dock South Coil receives liquid from the high pressure receiver. The evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporator. The evaporator contains a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporator and is returned to the main suction accumulator.

Main Suction Accumulator



The purpose of the main suction accumulator is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The main suction accumulator receives vapor from the flooded accumulators and separates any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the main suction accumulator drains by gravity into the liquid transfer vessel. The main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the main suction accumu

lator contains low pressure vapor ammonia.



Liquid Transfer Vessel



The purpose of the liquid transfer vessel is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration system back to the high pressure receivers. The liquid transfer vessel receives liquid from the main suction accumulator. Once the liquid level in the liquid transfer vessel reaches the float switch, the three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer vessel to become subject to high pressure and allowing the liquid to drain by gravity into High Pressure Receiver 1. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer vessel can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.

Compressors



The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the main suction accumulator and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.

Evaporative Condensers



The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receivers and thermosyphon vessel. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receivers and thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condensers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Thermosyphon Vessel



The purpose of the the

rmosyphon vessel is to provide a supply of liquid ammonia necessary to cool the oil in the compressors. The thermosyphon vessel receives high pressure liquid from the condensers and supplies high pressure liquid to the thermosyphon oil cooler on each screw compressor. Excess liquid in the thermosyphon vessel is piped to High Pressure Receiver 1. High pressure ammonia vapor formed in each oil cooler is returned to the thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the thermosyphon vessel contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Oil Cooler



The purpose of the oil coolers is to remove heat from the oil being circulated through them. The oil coolers receive liquid from the thermosyphon vessel. High pressure liquid and vapor exits the oil coolers and is returned to the thermosyphon vessel. Under normal conditions, the oil coolers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Safety Systems



The machinery room and refrigerated rooms are each equipped with ammonia detection. The detection system is interlocked with the refrigeration system controls as follows:

Ammonia concentration monitors are installed outside the machinery room to display the current concentration inside the room;



If the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm in the machinery room, audible and visual alarms are activated outside the room. Additionally, the emergency ventilation rate of the fan is activated.



If the ammonia concentration exceeds 25 ppm in the refrigerated rooms, an auto-dialer sends a notification to necessary personnel. 



The Emergency Control Box (ECB) is installed on the outside wall of the machinery room and contains four (4) valves.



Valve #1: High to Low Pressure Control Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3 (AV-205): High Side Discharge Valve HPR 1

Valve #4 (AV-206): High Side Discharge Valve HPR 2



Opening Valve #1 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low

pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #3 (AV-205) will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system through High Pressure Receiver 1. Opening Valve #3 (AV-206) will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system through High Pressure Receiver 2. 



Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.

High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.

Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.



All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:

Each relief valve has a set pressure equal to or less than the MAWP of the equipment that the relief valve protects;

Each relief valve has a capacity which meets or exceeds the requirement of ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.3.8;

All relief valves are connected to a common manifold which terminates to atmosphere, 7.25 ft above the roof;



Most relief valve assemblie

s are equipped with a relief vent indicator (RVI) to assist in recognizing that an overpressure event has occurred. Indicator flags are mounted to the shaft of the RVI on the outside of the housing. A paddle is set such that any sudden flow in the relief vent line pushes it down simultaneously raising the flags which then provide a clear signal that a relief valve has lifted. Stoppers mounted to the exterior prevent the flag/shaft from rotating more than the 90? swing;



The main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high liquid level in the vessel. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.



Process Classification



The ammonia refrigeration system at Mountain View Cold Storage consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Mountain View Cold Storage is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Mountain View Cold Storage has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Mountain View Cold Storage facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are

made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active logbook of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Mountain View Cold Storage has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Mountain View Cold Storage's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Mountain View Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Mountain View Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Mountain View Cold Storage's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Mountain View Cold Storage's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Mountain View Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is comple

ted (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Mountain View Cold Storage has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Mountain View Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Mountain View Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Mountain View Cold Storage will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
